baseline: Federalism differs from confederalism, in which the general level of government is subordinate to the regional level, and from devolution within a unitary state, in which the regional level of government is subordinate to the general level.

prompts: Federalism allows states to be large and diverse , mitigating the risk of
baseline: Federalism allows states to be large and diverse, mitigating the risk of a tyrannical government through centralization of powers.

prompts: Many countries have implemented federal systems of government with varying degree of central
baseline: Many countries have implemented federal systems of government with varying degree of central and regional sovereignty.

prompts: The federal government of these countries can be divided into minimalistic federations
baseline: The federal government of these countries can be divided into minimalistic federations, consisting of only two sub-federal units or multi-regional, those that consist of three to dozens of regional governments.

prompts: In general , two extremes of federalism can be distinguished : at one
baseline: In general, two extremes of federalism can be distinguished: at one extreme, the strong federal state is almost completely unitary, with few powers reserved for local governments; while at the other extreme, the national government may be a federal state in name only, being a confederation in actuality.

prompts: In 1999 , the Government of Canada established the Forum of
baseline: In 1999, the Government of Canada established the Forum of Federations as an international network for exchange of best practices among federal and federalizing countries.

prompts: In Europe , " federalist " is sometimes used to describe those
baseline: In Europe, "federalist" is sometimes used to describe those who favor a common federal government, with distributed power at regional, national and supranational levels.

prompts: In the United States , federalism originally referred to belief in
baseline: In the United States, federalism originally referred to belief in a stronger central government.

prompts: Constitution was being drafted , the Federalist Party supported a stronger central
baseline: Constitution was being drafted, the Federalist Party supported a stronger central government, while "Anti-Federalists" wanted a weaker central government.

prompts: Constitution was written as a replacement
baseline: Constitution was written as a replacement for the Articles of Confederation, under which the United States was a loose confederation with a weak central government.

prompts: In contrast , Europe has a greater history of unitary states than North America , thus European " federalism " argues for a weaker
baseline: In contrast, Europe has a greater history of unitary states than North America, thus European "federalism" argues for a weaker central government, relative to a unitary state.

prompts: As the power of the U.S. federal government has increased , some people
baseline: As the power of the U.S. federal government has increased, some people have perceived a much more unitary state than they believe the Founding Fathers intended.

prompts: Most people politically advocating " federalism " in the United States argue in favor of
baseline: Most people politically advocating "federalism" in the United States argue in favor of limiting the powers of the federal government, especially the judiciary (see Federalist Society, New Federalism).

prompts: The contemporary concept of federalism came about with the creation of an entirely new system of government that provided for democratic representation
baseline: The contemporary concept of federalism came about with the creation of an entirely new system of government that provided for democratic representation at two governing levels simultaneously, which was implemented in the US Constitution.

prompts: In the United States implementation of federalism , a bicameral general government , consisting of a chamber
baseline: In the United States implementation of federalism, a bicameral general government, consisting of a chamber of popular representation proportional to population (the House of Representatives), and a chamber of equal State-based representation consisting of two delegates per State (the Senate), was overlaid upon the pre-existing regional governments of the thirteen independent States.

prompts: With each level of government allocated a defined sphere of powers
baseline: With each level of government allocated a defined sphere of powers, under a written constitution and the rule of law (that is, subject to the independent third-party arbitration of a supreme court in competence disputes), the two levels were thus brought into a coordinate relationship  for the first time.

prompts: In 1946 , Kenneth Wheare observed that the two
baseline: In 1946, Kenneth Wheare observed that the two levels of government in the US were "co-equally supreme".

prompts: In this , he echoed the perspective of American founding father James Madison
baseline: In this, he echoed the perspective of American founding father James Madison who saw the several States as forming "distinct and independent portions of the supremacy" in relation to the general government.

prompts: In almost all federations the central government enjoys the powers of
baseline: In almost all federations the central government enjoys the powers of foreign policy and national defense as exclusive federal powers.

prompts: The constitutions of Germany and the United States provide that all powers
baseline: The constitutions of Germany and the United States provide that all powers not specifically granted to the federal government are retained by the states.

prompts: The Constitution of some countries , like Canada and India , state that powers not explicitly granted to the provincial
baseline: The Constitution of some countries, like Canada and India, state that powers not explicitly granted to the provincial/state governments are retained by the federal government.

prompts: Much like the US system , the Australian Constitution allocates to the Federal
baseline: Much like the US system, the Australian Constitution allocates to the Federal government (the Commonwealth of Australia) the power to make laws about certain specified matters which were considered too difficult for the States to manage, so that the States retain all other areas of responsibility.

prompts: However , strictly speaking Spain is not a federation , but a system of asymmetric devolved government within a
baseline: However, strictly speaking Spain is not a federation, but a system of asymmetric devolved government within a unitary state.

prompts: It is common that during the historical evolution of a federation there is a gradual movement
baseline: It is common that during the historical evolution of a federation there is a gradual movement of power from the component states to the centre, as the federal government acquires additional powers, sometimes to deal with unforeseen circumstances.

prompts: The acquisition of new powers by a federal government may occur through formal constitutional
baseline: The acquisition of new powers by a federal government may occur through formal constitutional amendment or simply through a broadening of the interpretation of a government's existing constitutional powers given by the courts.

prompts: Usually , a federation is formed at two levels : the central government and the regions ( states , provinces , territories ) , and little to nothing is said about second or
baseline: Usually, a federation is formed at two levels: the central government and the regions (states, provinces, territories), and little to nothing is said about second or third level administrative political entities.

prompts: Each state is divided into municipalities (
baseline: Each state is divided into municipalities (municípios) with their own legislative council (câmara de vereadores) and a mayor (prefeito), which are partly autonomous from both Federal and State Government.

prompts: Mexico is an intermediate case , in that municipalities are granted full - autonomy
baseline: Mexico is an intermediate case, in that municipalities are granted full-autonomy by the federal constitution and their existence as autonomous entities (municipio libre, "free municipality") is established by the federal government and cannot be revoked by the states' constitutions.

prompts: In its foundation , it is federal , not national ; in the sources from which the ordinary powers of the Government are drawn , it is
baseline: In its foundation, it is federal, not national; in the sources from which the ordinary powers of the Government are drawn, it is partly federal, and partly national..." This stems from the fact that states in the US maintain all sovereignty that they do not yield to the federation by their own consent.

prompts: This was reaffirmed by the Tenth Amendment to the United States Constitution , which reserves all powers and
baseline: This was reaffirmed by the Tenth Amendment to the United States Constitution, which reserves all powers and rights that are not delegated to the Federal Government as left to the States and to the people.

prompts: Alternatively , or in addition to this practice , the members of an upper house may be indirectly elected by the government
baseline: Alternatively, or in addition to this practice, the members of an upper house may be indirectly elected by the government or legislature of the component states, as occurred in the United States prior to 1913, or be actual members or delegates of the state governments, as, for example, is the case in the German Bundesrat and in the Council of the European Union.

prompts: In Canada , the provincial governments represent regional interests and
baseline: In Canada, the provincial governments represent regional interests and negotiate directly with the central government.

prompts: In Canada , federalism typically implies opposition to sovereigntist movements ( most
baseline: In Canada, federalism typically implies opposition to sovereigntist movements (most commonly Quebec separatism).

prompts: Federalism is sometimes viewed in the context of international negotiation as " the best system for integrating diverse nations ,
baseline: Federalism is sometimes viewed in the context of international negotiation as "the best system for integrating diverse nations, ethnic groups, or combatant parties, all of whom may have cause to fear control by an overly powerful center." However, those skeptical of federal prescriptions sometimes believe that increased regional autonomy can lead to secession or dissolution of the nation.

prompts: Theories adding philosophic backing to its own conceptualizations from such ideas as diplomatic recognition and the sovereign state 's right to exist as if it
baseline: Theories adding philosophic backing to its own conceptualizations from such ideas as diplomatic recognition and the sovereign state's right to exist as if it extended beyond territorial nation-state in an international structure, to an intranational structure of the voluntary association of those with similar social world views being codified legal frameworks to themselves, within their own sphere of interaction, under a federal government of a particular nation state and relying on infrastructural power for implementation.

prompts: Corporative federalism is a system of federalism not based on the common
baseline: Corporative federalism is a system of federalism not based on the common federalist idea of relative land area or nearest spheres of influence for governance, but on fiduciary jurisdiction to corporate personhood in which groups that are considered incorporated members of their own prerogative structure by willed agreement can delegate their individual effective legislature within the overall government.

prompts: Theories adding philosophic backing to its own conceptualizations from such ideas as diplomatic recognition and the sovereign state 's right to exist as if it
baseline: Theories adding philosophic backing to its own conceptualizations from such ideas as diplomatic recognition and the sovereign state's right to exist as if it extended beyond territorial nation-state in an international structure, to an intranational structure of the voluntary association of those with similar social world views being codified legal frameworks to themselves, within their own sphere of interaction, under a federal government of a particular nation state and relying on infrastructural power for implementation.

prompts: This government - related article is a
baseline: This government-related article is a stub.

prompts: Dual federalism , also known as layer - cake federalism or divided sovereignty , is
baseline: Dual federalism, also known as layer-cake federalism or divided sovereignty, is a political arrangement in which power is divided between the federal and state governments in clearly defined terms, with state governments exercising those powers accorded to them without interference from the federal government.

prompts: The system of dual / joint federalism in the United States is a product of
baseline: The system of dual/joint federalism in the United States is a product of the backlash against the Articles of Confederation, ratified in 1781, which established a very weak federal government with the powers to declare war, make treaties, and maintain an army.

prompts: Fueled by Shays ' Rebellion and an economy faltering under the inability
baseline: Fueled by Shays' Rebellion and an economy faltering under the inability of the federal government to pay the debt from the American Revolution, a group later known as the Federalists generated support for a strong central government and called for a Constitutional Convention in 1787 to reconsider the Articles.

prompts: Rejecting both confederal and unitary systems , they based the new American
baseline: Rejecting both confederal and unitary systems, they based the new American government on a new theory of federalism, a system of shared sovereignty that delegates some powers to the federal government and reserves other powers for the states.

prompts: Among other powers , the federal legislature could now tax citizens and maintain
baseline: Among other powers, the federal legislature could now tax citizens and maintain a standing military, and had exclusive power over regulating interstate commerce and coining currency.

prompts: In addition , while Article Six of the Constitution stipulated that federal law
baseline: In addition, while Article Six of the Constitution stipulated that federal law in pursuit of constitutionally assigned ends overrode any contradictory state law, the power of the national government was held in check by the Bill of Rights – particularly the Tenth Amendment, which limited federal governmental powers to only those specified in the Constitution.

prompts: The states ' motives for such a debate have been largely understood as a method
baseline: The states' motives for such a debate have been largely understood as a method for ensuring a strong voice in the federal government so as to maintain a desired degree of sovereignty.

prompts: Since the initial division of state and federal powers – collectively , the system of dual federalism – put forth by the
baseline: Since the initial division of state and federal powers – collectively, the system of dual federalism – put forth by the Constitution, several seminal court cases have helped further clarify the purview of the federal government.

prompts: Although the ability to charter a bank had not been explicitly granted to the federal
baseline: Although the ability to charter a bank had not been explicitly granted to the federal government in the Constitution, federalist proponents argued such action as necessary for the federal government to exercise its constitutional power to “tax, borrow, and regulate interstate commerce.”

prompts: While the constitutionality of some aspects implied by the case
baseline: While the constitutionality of some aspects implied by the case remained vague, the decision once more reaffirmed the supremacy of federal law and diminished the power of state-sanctioned protectionism.

prompts: In protest and spearheaded by Vice President John Calhoun , South Carolina formulated a " nullification
baseline: In protest and spearheaded by Vice President John Calhoun, South Carolina formulated a "nullification doctrine", in effect claiming a state's ability to ignore federal law, and rejected the tariff.

prompts: The situation became especially serious when President Jackson ordered federal troops into
baseline: The situation became especially serious when President Jackson ordered federal troops into Charleston, though crisis was averted by the drafting of a new tariff to which both sides agreed.

prompts: The crisis illustrated an example of conflicting ideologies on state
baseline: The crisis illustrated an example of conflicting ideologies on state and federal power that was not resolved through the courts, but with discussion between elected officials.

prompts: While some Southern states resisted economic actions of the federal government , several Northern states balked at federal requirements
baseline: While some Southern states resisted economic actions of the federal government, several Northern states balked at federal requirements regarding slavery.

prompts: Prigg was charged according to Pennsylvania law , which considered such an action
baseline: Prigg was charged according to Pennsylvania law, which considered such an action a felony, while Prigg argued that he had been duly appointed for the task and was within the bounds of the federal Fugitive Slave Act of 1793.

prompts: Scott , a slave who had been brought to the free
baseline: Scott, a slave who had been brought to the free state of Illinois but later returned to slave-holding jurisdictions, and who had pursued emancipation through the federal courts, remained a slave.

prompts: The Civil War brought to a head many of the fundamental disagreements concerning the extent of
baseline: The Civil War brought to a head many of the fundamental disagreements concerning the extent of state and federal powers which presidential candidates Lincoln and Douglas had debated between 1858 and 1860.

prompts: Douglas , an advocate of federal government limited by a strict
baseline: Douglas, an advocate of federal government limited by a strict interpretation of the Constitution, championed the vision of America as “the confederation of the sovereign states".

prompts: Lincoln , meanwhile , envisioned a more active federal government and more integrated national community , with the purview of states limited to only "
baseline: Lincoln, meanwhile, envisioned a more active federal government and more integrated national community, with the purview of states limited to only "those things that pertain exclusively to themselves—that are local in their nature, that have no connection with the general government".

prompts: Many of these questions would be resolved by actions taken
baseline: Many of these questions would be resolved by actions taken by the North’s federal government during the course of the fighting during the years after the debates.

prompts: Actions taken by the North during the war , including the conscription of
baseline: Actions taken by the North during the war, including the conscription of soldiers into a national army, as provided by the Enrollment Act of March 1863, and expanded federal control over banking with the 1863 National Banking Act, resulting in a much more robust national government in postbellum America.

prompts: There exists debate over whether this increase in federal power was achieved against states ’
baseline: There exists debate over whether this increase in federal power was achieved against states’ will or whether such expanded powers were granted by the states.

prompts: After the Civil War , the federal government began expanding its powers
baseline: After the Civil War, the federal government began expanding its powers, primarily concerning itself with regulating commerce and civil rights, originally considered the domain of state governments.

prompts: This period brought about debate on whether the federal government could make these amendments ,
baseline: This period brought about debate on whether the federal government could make these amendments, some arguing that this was an infringement on states' rights.

prompts: However , during this time period the public began to believe that
baseline: However, during this time period the public began to believe that the federal government was responsible for defending civil liberties even though previously the idea was that a strong central government would be the biggest detriment to personal freedom.

prompts: Industrialization , economic modernization , and conditions surrounding the Great Depression
baseline: Industrialization, economic modernization, and conditions surrounding the Great Depression elevated commerce to a more national level, so there was an overlap in the powers of the federal government and the states.

prompts: The federal government , using the Commerce Clause , passed national policies to
baseline: The federal government, using the Commerce Clause, passed national policies to regulate the economy.

prompts: This , in addition to the New Deal policies , led to the federal
baseline: This, in addition to the New Deal policies, led to the federal government and the states working together more, ending the era of dual federalism and moving America into cooperative federalism.

prompts: As opposed to a clear transition from dual federalism to cooperative federalism , some political scientists say there was a
baseline: As opposed to a clear transition from dual federalism to cooperative federalism, some political scientists say there was a much more complicated relationship between the states and the federal government.

prompts: Rather than a competition for power , the powers of the state
baseline: Rather than a competition for power, the powers of the state and federal government change according to national political movements and their agendas; a dynamic that existed both before and after the New Deal.

prompts: Other political scientists see dual federalism ending much earlier than
baseline: Other political scientists see dual federalism ending much earlier than the New Deal; This would have been the beginning of cooperative federalism as the federal government identified a problem, set up the basic outline of the program to address the problem, and make money available to fund that program, and then turning over much of the responsibility for implementing and running the program to the states and localities.

prompts: Daniel Elazar argues that there was substantial cooperation among the states and federal government beginning in the 19th
baseline: Daniel Elazar argues that there was substantial cooperation among the states and federal government beginning in the 19th century, leading up to the Civil War and several political scientists assert that starting from the 1870s and throughout the Progressive Era, the federal government and states worked together to create national policies.

prompts: The federations of Australia , Canada , and Switzerland most closely resemble the model of
baseline: The federations of Australia, Canada, and Switzerland most closely resemble the model of American dual federalism in which fundamental governmental powers are divided between the federal and state governments, with the states exercising broad powers.

prompts: While the American federalist system allocates both legislative and administrative powers to each division of government , European federations have historically allocated legislative powers to
baseline: While the American federalist system allocates both legislative and administrative powers to each division of government, European federations have historically allocated legislative powers to the federal government and left constituents to administer and implement these laws.

prompts: Most western federalist systems in recent years have drifted away from autonomous
baseline: Most western federalist systems in recent years have drifted away from autonomous levels of governments with strong state powers and moved toward more centralized federal governments, as seen in the American government's transition from dual to cooperative federalism.

prompts: The Canadian and Australian federal systems closely resemble the American construct
baseline: The Canadian and Australian federal systems closely resemble the American construct of dual federalism in that their legislative and executive powers are allocated in the same policy area to a single level of government.

prompts: In contrast , some federal structures , such as those of Germany , Austria , and Switzerland , consist of federal governments exercising broad legislative powers
baseline: In contrast, some federal structures, such as those of Germany, Austria, and Switzerland, consist of federal governments exercising broad legislative powers and constituent governments allocated the power to administer such legislation in a style similar to cooperative federalism.

prompts: The Australian Constitution was designed to enumerate a limited range
baseline: The Australian Constitution was designed to enumerate a limited range of federal powers and leave the rest to the states.

prompts: The Canadian Constitution , in contrast , assigned all residual powers
baseline: The Canadian Constitution, in contrast, assigned all residual powers to the federal government and enumerated a complete list of provincial powers.

prompts: The federations operate chiefly through legislation produced by the federal
baseline: The federations operate chiefly through legislation produced by the federal government and left to the Länder or state governments to implement.

prompts: Included in their 1960 report Goals for Americans : The Report of the President 's Commission on National Goals was " The Federal
baseline: Included in their 1960 report Goals for Americans: The Report of the President's Commission on National Goals was "The Federal System", a report by political scientist Morton Grodzins.

prompts: In this report , Grodzins first coined the terms "
baseline: In this report, Grodzins first coined the terms "layer cake federalism" and "marble cake federalism." He used the metaphor of a layer cake to describe the system of dual federalism, the separated layers of the cake symbolizing how distinct spheres of power that the state and federal governments have not been inhabited.

prompts: He contrasted this with marble cake , which he saw as descriptive of
baseline: He contrasted this with marble cake, which he saw as descriptive of federalism's status in 1960, the swirling indistinct boundaries of the cake symbolizing the overlapping and concurrent duties of the state and federal governments.

prompts: In 1787 , the Convention almost immediately dropped its original purpose
baseline: In 1787, the Convention almost immediately dropped its original purpose of editing the Articles and instead drafted a new Constitution of the United States.

prompts: In addition , while Article Six of the Constitution stipulated that federal law
baseline: In addition, while Article Six of the Constitution stipulated that federal law in pursuit of constitutionally assigned ends overrode any contradictory state law, the power of the national government was held in check by the Bill of Rights – particularly the Tenth Amendment, which limited federal governmental powers to only those specified in the Constitution.

prompts: Since the initial division of state and federal powers – collectively , the system of dual federalism – put forth by the
baseline: Since the initial division of state and federal powers – collectively, the system of dual federalism – put forth by the Constitution, several seminal court cases have helped further clarify the purview of the federal government.

prompts: Although the ability to charter a bank had not been explicitly granted to the federal
baseline: Although the ability to charter a bank had not been explicitly granted to the federal government in the Constitution, federalist proponents argued such action as necessary for the federal government to exercise its constitutional power to “tax, borrow, and regulate interstate commerce.”

prompts: The Supreme Court , in essence , backed Alexander Hamilton 's
baseline: The Supreme Court, in essence, backed Alexander Hamilton's interpretation of the Constitution over Thomas Jefferson.

prompts: Douglas , an advocate of federal government limited by a strict
baseline: Douglas, an advocate of federal government limited by a strict interpretation of the Constitution, championed the vision of America as “the confederation of the sovereign states".

prompts: After the Civil War , Congress amended the Constitution to
baseline: After the Civil War, Congress amended the Constitution to guarantee certain rights for citizens.

prompts: Constitutions with delegations of broad powers to the state level of government that resemble the Constitution of
baseline: Constitutions with delegations of broad powers to the state level of government that resemble the Constitution of the United States include the Constitution of Australia and the Constitution of Canada.

prompts: The Australian Constitution was designed to enumerate a limited range
baseline: The Australian Constitution was designed to enumerate a limited range of federal powers and leave the rest to the states.

prompts: The Canadian Constitution , in contrast , assigned all residual powers
baseline: The Canadian Constitution, in contrast, assigned all residual powers to the federal government and enumerated a complete list of provincial powers.

prompts: The Austrian Constitution , Constitution of Germany , and Swiss Constitution enumerate few policy fields
baseline: The Austrian Constitution, Constitution of Germany, and Swiss Constitution enumerate few policy fields exclusive to the states, but enumerate extensive concurrent powers.

prompts: In addition , while Article Six of the Constitution stipulated that federal law
baseline: In addition, while Article Six of the Constitution stipulated that federal law in pursuit of constitutionally assigned ends overrode any contradictory state law, the power of the national government was held in check by the Bill of Rights – particularly the Tenth Amendment, which limited federal governmental powers to only those specified in the Constitution.

prompts: In the decades before the Civil War , both Northern and Southern states clashed with the national
baseline: In the decades before the Civil War, both Northern and Southern states clashed with the national government over perceived overreaches in its power.

baseline: They can also be grouped based on their body polity type, such as emirate, provincial, republican or state federal systems.

baseline: In Europe, "federalist" is sometimes used to describe those who favor a common federal government, with distributed power at regional, national and supranational levels.

baseline: Dual federalism, also known as layer-cake federalism or divided sovereignty, is a political arrangement in which power is divided between the federal and state governments in clearly defined terms, with state governments exercising those powers accorded to them without interference from the federal government.

baseline: The system of dual/joint federalism in the United States is a product of the backlash against the Articles of Confederation, ratified in 1781, which established a very weak federal government with the powers to declare war, make treaties, and maintain an army.

baseline: Fueled by Shays' Rebellion and an economy faltering under the inability of the federal government to pay the debt from the American Revolution, a group later known as the Federalists generated support for a strong central government and called for a Constitutional Convention in 1787 to reconsider the Articles.

prompts: Among other powers , the federal legislature could now tax citizens and maintain
baseline: Among other powers, the federal legislature could now tax citizens and maintain a standing military, and had exclusive power over regulating interstate commerce and coining currency.

baseline: In addition, while Article Six of the Constitution stipulated that federal law in pursuit of constitutionally assigned ends overrode any contradictory state law, the power of the national government was held in check by the Bill of Rights – particularly the Tenth Amendment, which limited federal governmental powers to only those specified in the Constitution.

baseline: Federalism is a mode of government that combines a general government (the central or federal government) with regional governments (provincial, state, cantonal, territorial, or other sub-unit governments) in a single political system, dividing the powers between the two.

baseline: Examples of a federation or federal province or state include Argentina, Australia, Austria, Belgium, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Brazil, Canada, Ethiopia, Germany, India, Iraq, Malaysia, Mexico, Micronesia, Nepal, Nigeria, Pakistan, Russia, Somalia, South Sudan, Sudan, Switzerland, the United Arab Emirates, the United States, and Venezuela.

baseline: Some characterize the European Union as the pioneering example of federalism in a multi-state setting, in a concept termed the "federal union of states".

baseline: It was in this sense that James Madison in "The Federalist No. 39" had referred to the new US Constitution as "neither a national nor a federal Constitution, but a composition of both" (i.e. as constituting neither a single large unitary state nor a league/confederation among several small states, but a hybrid of the two).

baseline: According to Daniel Ziblatt, there are four competing theoretical explanations in the academic literature for the adoption of federal systems:

prompts: Proponents for federal systems have historically argued that the power
baseline: Proponents for federal systems have historically argued that the power-sharing inherent in federal systems reduces both domestic security threats and foreign threats.

prompts: Many countries have implemented federal systems of government with varying degree of central
baseline: Many countries have implemented federal systems of government with varying degree of central and regional sovereignty.

prompts: The federal government of these countries can be divided into minimalistic federations
baseline: The federal government of these countries can be divided into minimalistic federations, consisting of only two sub-federal units or multi-regional, those that consist of three to dozens of regional governments.

prompts: They can also be grouped based on their
baseline: They can also be grouped based on their body polity type, such as emirate, provincial, republican or state federal systems.

prompts: Another way to study federated countries is by categorizing them
baseline: Another way to study federated countries is by categorizing them into those whose entire territory is federated as opposed to only part of its territory comprising the federal portion of the country.

prompts: Some federal systems are national systems while
baseline: Some federal systems are national systems while others, like the European Union are supra national.

prompts: In general , two extremes of federalism can be distinguished : at one
baseline: In general, two extremes of federalism can be distinguished: at one extreme, the strong federal state is almost completely unitary, with few powers reserved for local governments; while at the other extreme, the national government may be a federal state in name only, being a confederation in actuality.

prompts: In 1999 , the Government of Canada established the Forum of
baseline: In 1999, the Government of Canada established the Forum of Federations as an international network for exchange of best practices among federal and federalizing countries.

prompts: In Europe , " federalist " is sometimes used to describe those
baseline: In Europe, "federalist" is sometimes used to describe those who favor a common federal government, with distributed power at regional, national and supranational levels.

prompts: Although there are medieval and early modern examples of European states which used confederal and federal
baseline: Although there are medieval and early modern examples of European states which used confederal and federal systems, contemporary European federalism originated in post-war Europe; one of the more important initiatives was Winston Churchill's speech in Zürich in 1946.

prompts: As the power of the U.S. federal government has increased , some people
baseline: As the power of the U.S. federal government has increased, some people have perceived a much more unitary state than they believe the Founding Fathers intended.

prompts: Most people politically advocating " federalism " in the United States argue in favor of
baseline: Most people politically advocating "federalism" in the United States argue in favor of limiting the powers of the federal government, especially the judiciary (see Federalist Society, New Federalism).

prompts: In a federation , the division of power between federal and regional governments is usually outlined in the constitution
baseline: In a federation, the division of power between federal and regional governments is usually outlined in the constitution.

prompts: Component states often also possess their own constitutions which they may amend as they see
baseline: Component states often also possess their own constitutions which they may amend as they see fit, although in the event of conflict the federal constitution usually takes precedence.

prompts: In almost all federations the central government enjoys the powers of
baseline: In almost all federations the central government enjoys the powers of foreign policy and national defense as exclusive federal powers.

prompts: The constitutions of Germany and the United States provide that all powers
baseline: The constitutions of Germany and the United States provide that all powers not specifically granted to the federal government are retained by the states.

prompts: The Constitution of some countries , like Canada and India , state that powers not explicitly granted to the provincial
baseline: The Constitution of some countries, like Canada and India, state that powers not explicitly granted to the provincial/state governments are retained by the federal government.

prompts: Much like the US system , the Australian Constitution allocates to the Federal
baseline: Much like the US system, the Australian Constitution allocates to the Federal government (the Commonwealth of Australia) the power to make laws about certain specified matters which were considered too difficult for the States to manage, so that the States retain all other areas of responsibility.

prompts: It is common that during the historical evolution of a federation there is a gradual movement
baseline: It is common that during the historical evolution of a federation there is a gradual movement of power from the component states to the centre, as the federal government acquires additional powers, sometimes to deal with unforeseen circumstances.

prompts: The acquisition of new powers by a federal government may occur through formal constitutional
baseline: The acquisition of new powers by a federal government may occur through formal constitutional amendment or simply through a broadening of the interpretation of a government's existing constitutional powers given by the courts.

prompts: Each state is divided into municipalities (
baseline: Each state is divided into municipalities (municípios) with their own legislative council (câmara de vereadores) and a mayor (prefeito), which are partly autonomous from both Federal and State Government.

prompts: Mexico is an intermediate case , in that municipalities are granted full - autonomy
baseline: Mexico is an intermediate case, in that municipalities are granted full-autonomy by the federal constitution and their existence as autonomous entities (municipio libre, "free municipality") is established by the federal government and cannot be revoked by the states' constitutions.

prompts: Moreover , the federal constitution determines which powers and competencies belong exclusively to the
baseline: Moreover, the federal constitution determines which powers and competencies belong exclusively to the municipalities and not to the constituent states.

prompts: For example , James Madison ( author of the United States Constitution ) wrote in Federalist Paper
baseline: For example, James Madison (author of the United States Constitution) wrote in Federalist Paper No. 39 that the US Constitution "is in strictness neither a national nor a federal constitution; but a composition of both.

prompts: In its foundation , it is federal , not national ; in the sources from which the ordinary powers of the Government are drawn , it is
baseline: In its foundation, it is federal, not national; in the sources from which the ordinary powers of the Government are drawn, it is partly federal, and partly national..." This stems from the fact that states in the US maintain all sovereignty that they do not yield to the federation by their own consent.

prompts: This was reaffirmed by the Tenth Amendment to the United States Constitution , which reserves all powers and
baseline: This was reaffirmed by the Tenth Amendment to the United States Constitution, which reserves all powers and rights that are not delegated to the Federal Government as left to the States and to the people.

prompts: The structures of most federal governments incorporate mechanisms to protect
baseline: The structures of most federal governments incorporate mechanisms to protect the rights of component states.

prompts: One method , known as ' intrastate federalism ' , is to directly represent
baseline: One method, known as 'intrastate federalism', is to directly represent the governments of component states in federal political institutions.

prompts: A federal upper house may be based on a special
baseline: A federal upper house may be based on a special scheme of apportionment, as is the case in the senates of the United States and Australia, where each state is represented by an equal number of senators irrespective of the size of its population.

prompts: The lower house of a federal legislature is usually directly elected , with apportionment
baseline: The lower house of a federal legislature is usually directly elected, with apportionment in proportion to population, although states may sometimes still be guaranteed a certain minimum number of seats.

prompts: Federations often have special procedures for
baseline: Federations often have special procedures for amendment of the federal constitution.

prompts: As well as reflecting the federal structure of the state this may guarantee that the self
baseline: As well as reflecting the federal structure of the state this may guarantee that the self-governing status of the component states cannot be abolished without their consent.

prompts: Some federal constitutions also provide that certain constitutional amendments can not occur without the unanimous
baseline: Some federal constitutions also provide that certain constitutional amendments cannot occur without the unanimous consent of all states or of a particular state.

prompts: The German Basic Law provides that no amendment is admissible at all that would abolish the federal system
baseline: The German Basic Law provides that no amendment is admissible at all that would abolish the federal system.

baseline: Dual federalism, also known as layer-cake federalism or divided sovereignty, is a political arrangement in which power is divided between the federal and state governments in clearly defined terms, with state governments exercising those powers accorded to them without interference from the federal government.

prompts: The system of dual / joint federalism in the United States is a product of
baseline: The system of dual/joint federalism in the United States is a product of the backlash against the Articles of Confederation, ratified in 1781, which established a very weak federal government with the powers to declare war, make treaties, and maintain an army.

baseline: Fueled by Shays' Rebellion and an economy faltering under the inability of the federal government to pay the debt from the American Revolution, a group later known as the Federalists generated support for a strong central government and called for a Constitutional Convention in 1787 to reconsider the Articles.

prompts: Rejecting both confederal and unitary systems , they based the new American
baseline: Rejecting both confederal and unitary systems, they based the new American government on a new theory of federalism, a system of shared sovereignty that delegates some powers to the federal government and reserves other powers for the states.

prompts: Among other powers , the federal legislature could now tax citizens and maintain
baseline: Among other powers, the federal legislature could now tax citizens and maintain a standing military, and had exclusive power over regulating interstate commerce and coining currency.

baseline: In addition, while Article Six of the Constitution stipulated that federal law in pursuit of constitutionally assigned ends overrode any contradictory state law, the power of the national government was held in check by the Bill of Rights – particularly the Tenth Amendment, which limited federal governmental powers to only those specified in the Constitution.

baseline: In protest and spearheaded by Vice President John Calhoun, South Carolina formulated a "nullification doctrine", in effect claiming a state's ability to ignore federal law, and rejected the tariff.

baseline: The situation became especially serious when President Jackson ordered federal troops into Charleston, though crisis was averted by the drafting of a new tariff to which both sides agreed.

baseline: While some Southern states resisted economic actions of the federal government, several Northern states balked at federal requirements regarding slavery.

baseline: The Civil War brought to a head many of the fundamental disagreements concerning the extent of state and federal powers which presidential candidates Lincoln and Douglas had debated between 1858 and 1860.

prompts: Douglas , an advocate of federal government limited by a strict
baseline: Douglas, an advocate of federal government limited by a strict interpretation of the Constitution, championed the vision of America as “the confederation of the sovereign states".

baseline: Lincoln, meanwhile, envisioned a more active federal government and more integrated national community, with the purview of states limited to only "those things that pertain exclusively to themselves—that are local in their nature, that have no connection with the general government".

baseline: Actions taken by the North during the war, including the conscription of soldiers into a national army, as provided by the Enrollment Act of March 1863, and expanded federal control over banking with the 1863 National Banking Act, resulting in a much more robust national government in postbellum America.

baseline: There exists debate over whether this increase in federal power was achieved against states’ will or whether such expanded powers were granted by the states.

baseline: After the Civil War, the federal government began expanding its powers, primarily concerning itself with regulating commerce and civil rights, originally considered the domain of state governments.

baseline: This period brought about debate on whether the federal government could make these amendments, some arguing that this was an infringement on states' rights.
